channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Revenge and Unease Shadow Effort to Restore Order
item.description: The rebel leader who helped oust the Assad regime called on countries to hand over “criminals” who fled Syria. A top Kurdish commander criticized the United States, saying it was risking an ISIS resurgence.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: The Gold Rush at the Heart of a Civil War
item.description: Famine and ethnic cleansing stalk Sudan. Yet the gold trade is booming, enriching generals and propelling the fight.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sudanese soldiers drove through a destroyed market in Sudan’s capital, Khartoum, in April.

item.title: A Search in Syria for the Disappeared
item.description: Syrians raced to newly emptied prisons to reunite with loved ones snatched away by the brutal regime of Bashar al-Assad, but their quest sometimes took them to the morgue.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Berehulak and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times

item.title: Tangled and Troubling Legacy Pushes Romanians Further to the Right
item.description: An ultranationalist politician’s surge shows how many people would rather forget the country’s fascist past, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman holding a flag of the antisemitic Legionary Movement during a commemoration for its founder last month in a forest near Bucharest, Romania.

item.title: South Korean Police Raid President Yoon’s Office in Martial Law Inquiry
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol shows no sign of stepping down, as investigators raided his office and more members of his own party turned against him.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoon Suk Yeol, the president of South Korea, in his office in Seoul in 2022.

item.title: Syria After al-Assad’s Overthrow: What’s Happening and What Comes Next
item.description: Rebels are asserting control in Damascus as Israel and other countries carry out military operations.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fighter from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham on Tuesday near an entrance to Bashar al-Assad’s abandoned presidential palace in Damascus.

item.title: What Prince William’s Chat With Trump May Reveal About UK Diplomacy
item.description: A meeting between President-elect Donald J. Trump and Prince William showed Britain’s hope that the Windsors could help safeguard relations with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Oleg Nikishin/Getty Images
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump and Prince William met in Paris after a Notre-Dame reopening ceremony on Saturday. Mr. Trump said, “I had a great talk with the prince,” whom he described as “really, very handsome.”

item.title: U.K. Bans Puberty Blockers for Teens Indefinitely
item.description: A freeze placed this year on their use to treat gender dysphoria will remain in place for young people under 18, except in clinical trials, Britain’s government said.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Hollie Adams/Reuters
item.media:description: Wes Streeting, the health secretary, said he had received advice from medical experts that there was an unacceptable risk in prescribing puberty blockers without further research into their impact.

item.title: Scholz Calls for Confidence Vote, in Step Toward German Elections
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz, who had few alternatives after his three-party coalition broke up, is widely expected to lose when Parliament takes up the measure on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Clemens Bilan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany with his cabinet on Wednesday.

item.title: How ‘Her Story,’ a Feminist Comedy, Came to Rule China’s Box Office
item.description: “Her Story” touches on sensitive topics in China, like censorship and gender inequality. But its humorous, nonconfrontational approach may have helped it pass censors.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Shao Yihui, right, the director of “Her Story,” a feminist-themed comedy that has become a box office hit in China, along with members of the cast at a premiere in Beijing.

item.title: North Korea Breaks Silence on South Korea’s Martial Law Declaration
item.description: In its first statement about the turmoil over President Yoon Suk Yeol’s martial law decree, the North said nothing about how inter-Korean relations might be affected.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the National Assembly in Seoul on Saturday, hours before a bid to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol failed.

item.title: Explosion in Afghanistan Kills Minister in Highest-Profile Blast Since Taliban’s Return
item.description: The government accused the Islamic State of being behind the attack, which struck at the heart of the Taliban’s power structure after years of essentially unchallenged dominance.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, Safiullah Padshah and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khalil Haqqani delivering remarks after Friday Prayer in Kabul in 2021. He was a leading figure in the Taliban’s rise to power in 2021.

item.title: Netanyahu Finally Takes the Stand in His Corruption Trial
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is accused of bribery, fraud and breach of trust in a trial that began four years ago. He has denied the charges.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Menahem Kahana
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu prepares to testify in his trial on corruption charges at the district court in Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: In Aleppo, Rebels Give a Sense of What Is to Come for Syria
item.description: Rebel fighters who took control of Aleppo about two weeks ago have promised security and continuity. Prices have skyrocketed, but residents express some hope for the future.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Haj Kadour and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Karam Al-Masri/Reuters
item.media:description: A damaged poster of former President Bashar al-Assad in Aleppo, Syria, last week.

item.title: Humbled in Syria, Putin Seeks Vindication in Ukraine
item.description: An ally’s downfall has prompted calls in Russia for a definitive victory closer to home.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers from Ukraine’s Herkules mobile air defense unit at a shooting range in Kyiv last month. The war is now “all or nothing” for Vladimir V. Putin, one analyst said.

item.title: Young Koreans, Seeing Democracy at Stake, Take to the Streets
item.description: South Korea’s night of martial law was a jolt for some members of a generation accused of political apathy. They say they aren’t going away.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: As Europe Looks for a Leader, Italy Thrives While France and Germany Teeter
item.description: With Germany and France mired in crisis, the government of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni looks like a haven of stability, turning the continent’s usual pattern on its head.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Alessandro Di Meo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy has worked to dispel fears about her party’s post-fascist roots by aligning with her European partners on key issues like support for Ukraine.

item.title: Milei Tames Inflation in Argentina With Painful Policies, Sparking Applause and Anger
item.description: A year after becoming president, Javier Milei has been praised inside and outside Argentina for reining in galloping inflation. But his economic policies have inflicted widespread hardship.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi, Lucía Cholakian Herrera and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Javier Milei of Argentina speaking at an America First Policy Institute gala at Mar-a-Lago in Florida last month. President-elect Donald J. Trump has lauded Mr. Milei’s tenure in office.

item.title: A Father’s Search for His Missing Daughter in South Korea
item.description: A father’s 25-year search for his missing daughter in South Korea made him a tragic national symbol of unwavering parental devotion.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times

item.title: Assad’s Fall in Syria Renews Push for Justice on Crimes Committed by His Regime
item.description: It seems unlikely that deposed President Bashar al-Assad, who fled to Russia, will be forced to stand trial. That is not deterring activists who have worked for years to document his government’s crimes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: People celebrated in the center of Damascus, Syria’s capital, on Monday. The Assad family ruled the country brutally for more than 50 years.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The latest from Syria.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Damascus, Syria, yesterday.

item.title: How to Pack a ‘Go Bag’ for Extreme Weather
item.description: If the trend continues, extreme weather will occur more frequently. Here’s how experts suggest you prepare.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Sims
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: An extreme-weather go bag will eliminate the panic of wondering what to bring with you, and it may end up saving your life.

item.title: Canada’s Plan To Avoid Trump’s Tariffs Takes Shape
item.description: Two weeks after a Mar-a-Lago dinner with Donald J. Trump, details of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s plan to stave off a showdown with the United States are emerging.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Jennifer Gauthier/Reuters
item.media:description: Commercial trucks heading toward the U.S. border last month from South Surrey, British Columbia.

item.title: South Korea President Yoon Defends Martial Law Decree in Defiant Speech
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol vowed to “fight to the end,” despite the opposition’s push to impeach him and his own party’s demand that he resign.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Kim Hong-Ji/Reuters
item.media:description: Watching President Yoon Suk Yeol’s address at a railway station in Seoul on Thursday.

item.title: Syria’s New Leaders Balance Huge Struggles Amid Disorder
item.description: The rebels who seized control called for foreign help in prosecuting atrocities, while trying to restore order in a fractured country.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker, Cassandra Vinograd, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former detainee of the notorious Sednaya prison being treated at a hospital after being freed by rebels.

item.title: In Aleppo, Jubilant Syrians Return to a Ravaged City and Toppled Monuments
item.description: Though excitement and frenzy were on full display in some parts of Aleppo, the city is still gripped by uncertainty after the sudden end of a 13-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Young men, some of them rebel fighters, climbing on a giant statue that previously depicted Basel al-Assad, the former president Bashar al-Assad’s late brother, riding a horse on Wednesday in Aleppo, Syria.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: The Struggle to Create Order in Syria
item.description: Plus, China’s surprising box office hit.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A defaced portrait of President Bashar al-Assad in Damascus on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Strategy on Syria Risks ISIS Resurgence, Kurdish General Warns
item.description: Gen. Mazlum Kobani, commander of Kurdish forces in Syria, said recent decisions by the U.S. in Syria potentially “leaves a vacuum” that ISIS could take advantage of.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ahmed Mardnli/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Destroyed trucks loaded with weapons for a Kurdish-led force after a Turkish airstrike near Qamishli, northeastern Syria, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden’s Top Aides Race to Middle East as Militias Wield Power in Syria
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken plans to hold meetings in Jordan and Turkey. Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, is visiting Israel.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken left for the Middle East on Wednesday, where the main topic of his meetings will be the future governance of Syria.

item.title: Russian Navy Ships Have Left Key Syrian Port
item.description: Satellite images from last week and this week show that naval vessels docked at the port city of Tartus have left. According to marine tracking data, no cargo ships have entered or left Tartus since Monday.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Riley Mellen

item.title: Could Cats Become a Vector for Bird Flu?
item.description: A new study highlights the need for public health officials to ramp up bird flu surveillance in our feline companions.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Arin Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scientists worry that if a cat were simultaneously infected with H5N1 and a seasonal flu virus, the H5N1 virus could acquire mutations to spread efficiently among people.

item.title: Who Is Mohammed al-Bashir, Syria’s New Prime Minister?
item.description: Mr. al-Bashir previously headed a rebel-led administration in northwestern Syria. He has been tasked with running the country’s interim government until March.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mohammed al-Bashir during a news conference in the northwestern Syrian city of Idlib in November.

item.title: Who Set the Stage for al-Assad’s Ouster? There Are Different Answers in the U.S. and Israel.
item.description: President Biden says he weakened Russia, Iran and Hezbollah, laying the groundwork for Bashar al-Assad’s ouster. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says the Syrian leader would still be in power had he listened to American advice.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A defaced portrait of Bashar al-Assad at the Presidential Palace in Damascus, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: How Many People Have Died in Syria’s Civil War?
item.description: The United Nations and human rights organizations have faced challenges in counting all those killed and missing in the conflict that began in March 2011.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives look for bodies of loved ones who were taken or disappeared at the Sednaya Prison on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Administration Looks to Reinforce U.S.-China Ties Ahead of Trump’s Return
item.description: Senior Treasury officials are holding a final round of talks with a new round of economic volatility on the horizon.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Saul Loeb/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Top Treasury officials will travel to China this week to try and convince their Beijing peers to keep lines of communication open after President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office next month.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A wave of attacks on Syria.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Aaref Watad/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Syrian naval ships destroyed in an Israeli attack on the port city of Latakia.

item.title: Houthi Attacks Continue to Disrupt Shipping Industry As Israel-Hamas War Rages On
item.description: The transport route around the southern tip of Africa was once little used — but freighters are now forced to take it and are charging higher rates.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis and Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Capt. Tobias Kammann on his freighter, the Hanoi Express, docked in Hamburg, Germany. Ships’ access to the Suez Canal has been cut off for the last year by attackers in Yemen.

item.title: Trump Offers Confusing Clues on Syria
item.description: The president-elect faces hard choices about the country’s post-Assad future. His vows not to get involved might be hard to keep.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Umayyad Square in Damascus, Syria, on Tuesday, two days after President Bashar al-Assad fled the country and rebel forces took control of the capital.

item.title: A Northern Gaza Hospital Lacks Food and Water for Patients, Officials Say
item.description: The health ministry in Gaza said dozens of patients are at risk of death because the Indonesian Hospital does not have enough water and food to keep them alive.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Indonesian Hospital in the northern Gaza Strip after Israeli troops raided it in November 2023.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Vow Punishment for Atrocities Under Bashar al-Assad
item.description: The rebels who seized Damascus are trying to get a new government up and running, even as foreign powers like Israel and Turkey, and armed Syrian groups, fight for power.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad, Qasim Nauman and Thomas Fuller
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: A defaced portrait of the ousted Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, beside a highway in Damascus, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: French Court Finds Author Charles Onana Guilty of Denying Rwandan Genocide
item.description: Charles Onana and his publisher were fined for passages in a book that were found to have violated a French law making it illegal to deny an officially recognized genocide.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ben Curtis/Associated Press
item.media:description: Family photographs of some of those who died in the Rwandan genocide on display in the Kigali Genocide Memorial Center in Kigali, Rwanda, in 2014.

item.title: Uncertainty and Hope on the Road to and from Damascus
item.description: Thousands of Syrians have been traveling to and from the Lebanese border since the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Some families hoped to reunite with loved ones, while others are leaving amid an uncertain future.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cassel, Alessandro Pavone and Mark Boyer
item.media:credit: Alessandro Pavone for The New York Times

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Wave of Post-Assad Attacks
item.description: Plus, how Netflix brought a magical town to life.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Jalaa Marey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle entering the buffer zone with Syria.

item.title: A Tour of Assad’s Monumental Palace, With a Scruffy Rebel as a Guide
item.description: The televisions may be stripped away now, but a presidential residence still contains many remnants of a brutal reign.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Nicole Tung
item.media:description: Abu Oweis, a rebel fighter, in the office of a longtime senior adviser to Bashar al-Assad at the abandoned presidential palace in Damascus, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: Arrests Made in 2021 Crash That Killed Over 50 Migrants
item.description: U.S. and Guatemalan authorities said the arrests were linked to a human trafficking ring and a deadly 2021 traffic accident.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Cristina Chiquin/Reuters
item.media:description: Josefa Quino Canil De Zavala after being detained on Monday in a joint operation between Guatemalan and U.S. authorities for alleged involvement in a deadly 2021 truck accident that killed more than 50 migrants in southern Mexico.

item.title: Cyclist Rohan Dennis Pleads Guilty in Death of Wife Melissa Hoskins, Fellow Olympian
item.description: Rohan Dennis pleaded guilty this week to a lesser charge in the death of Melissa Hoskins last year, after he drove with her on the hood of a vehicle, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Jason Cairnduff/Reuters
item.media:description: Rohan Dennis pleaded guilty to creating a risk of harm. He faces seven years in prison.

item.title: Monarch Butterflies Are Recommended for Protected Status in U.S.
item.description: They would become the most commonly seen species to receive federal protection if the proposal is adopted.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Nic Coury for The New York Times

item.title: FIFA Bends Own Rules to Give Saudi Arabia 2034 World Cup
item.description: Critics objected to the bidding process, and human rights groups raised concerns about workplace safety for the migrants who will build the stadiums needed to host the event.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lee Smith/Reuters
item.media:description: Argentina players celebrating with the trophy after winning the World Cup in December 2022, in Qatar.

item.title: Sednaya Prison in Syria: What to Know
item.description: Amnesty International described it as a “human slaughterhouse,” where, other rights groups say, tens of thousands of people were detained, tortured and killed during the 13-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: A man praying inside a liberated cell in Sednaya prison, in the suburbs of Damascus, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: Trump Mocks Trudeau and Canada in Post on Tariffs and Trade
item.description: The president-elect’s mockery of Canada and its leader is the latest salvo after his promise to impose steep tariffs on Canadian exports.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Donald Trump listening during a meeting in 2019 with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada.

item.title: Arctic Tundra Has Long Helped Cool Earth. Now, It’s Fueling Warming.
item.description: Wildfires and thawing permafrost are causing the region to release more carbon dioxide than its plants remove, probably for the first time in thousands of years.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hill with an ice core, known as a pingo, in the Mackenzie River Delta, Northwest Territories.

item.title: Police Arrest 3 After Deadly Explosion in the Netherlands
item.description: The blast, which the mayor of The Hague called an “unprecedented disaster,” killed six people on Saturday morning.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Josh Walet/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An explosion and fire killed at least six people and destroyed part of an apartment building in The Hague, the Netherlands, on Saturday.

item.title: Protests in Kenya Demand Action Over a Spate of Brutal Murders of Women
item.description: Almost 100 women have been killed in the span of three months, the police say. Rights groups want President William Ruto to declare femicide a national crisis.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Simon Maina/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Nairobi, Kenya, on Tuesday to demand that the government take action to stop the killings of women and girls.

item.title: Israel Strikes Military Assets Across Syria to Keep Them From Rebels
item.description: Israel capitalized on the power vacuum in Syria to bomb targets across the country, saying it aims to keep weapons away from extremists.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath on Tuesday of an overnight strike on the Barzah scientific research center, which had been linked to the Syrian government’s chemical weapons program.

item.title: South Korea Martial Law Fallout: What to Know on Yoon’s Future
item.description: The president faces an accusation of insurrection and, in a first for a sitting leader, the possibility of arrest. Here’s what to know about his political future.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers near the National Assembly in Seoul last week after President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law.

item.title: On the Ground in Damascus as Syrians Chart a New Path
item.description: In a matter of days, Syria’s capital — once the stronghold of Bashar al-Assad’s government — became the epicenter of a new chapter in the country’s history after opposition forces overran the city. Christina Goldbaum, a New York Times correspondent, traveled to Damascus to find out how residents were reacting to the sudden breakthrough in the 13-year civil war as more than five decades of brutal rule by the Assad dynasty come to an end.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Nikolay Nikolov, Christina Shaman and Daniel Berehulak

item.title: South Korea’s Opposition Leader Determined to Oust President Yoon After Martial Law
item.description: Lee Jae-myung, the main opposition leader, is leading efforts to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol over his declaration of martial law. He could also be the next president.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, the leader of the opposition party, at his Democratic Party’s meeting room in the National Assembly in Seoul on Monday.

item.title: Prince William and Jacob Elordi Grow Beards That Spark Strong Feelings
item.description: Whether on Prince William, JD Vance or Jacob Elordi, facial hair gets people talking.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Justin Tallis
item.media:description: Prince William has had a beard at multiple public appearances in recent weeks.

item.title: In Georgia Protests, Echoes of Ukraine’s Past Revolutions
item.description: This former Soviet Republic has been rocked by anti-government demonstrations over the same issues that hurtled Ukraine into war — its relationship with Europe and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Daro Sulakauri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fireworks set off by protesters exploded around riot police during a demonstration in Tbilisi, Georgia, last week.

item.title: Here’s How Much Cleaner Energy Could Save America, in Lives and Money
item.description: Widespread adoption of heat pumps could prevent thousands of premature deaths and save billions on energy bills, according to a new analysis.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times

item.title: Lula, Brazil’s President, Is in ICU After Emergency Brain Surgery
item.description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil was in the hospital following the procedure. Doctors said the bleeding appeared to be linked to a fall in October.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Martin Varela Umpierrez/Reuters
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil is recovering from an “uneventful” emergency surgery, according to the hospital that treated him.

item.title: Taiwan Says China Has Deployed Largest Fleet of Ships in Decades
item.description: Taiwan is on high alert in response to China’s unannounced deployment of naval and Coast Guard ships, as tensions rise over U.S. support for the island.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: I-Hwa Cheng/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Taiwanese fighter jet landing in Hsinchu on Tuesday.
